awd_titl_txt: EAGER SitS: Bury and Forget Nitrogen Sensors Coupled With Remote Sensing for Soil Health
awd_abstract_narration:
Excess fertilizer application from farm fields results in nitrogen runoff which causes major drinking water contamination as well as commercial fishing and tourism industry decline. Therefore, it is vitally important to have accurate predictive nitrogen soil models that can help farmers reduce fertilizer use by knowing exactly what type of fertilizer to use and precisely when and where in a field to apply.  However, the accuracy of these soil models is lacking because soil nitrogen concentration data acquired at numerous points within a field is currently cost prohibitive and technically challenging.  This research will create low-cost sensors that can electrically transmit soil nitrogen levels (ammonium and nitrate ion concentration levels) from various soil depths and locations to a central hub so that data can be transmitted through the internet and analyzed remotely.  Sensors that can be fitted with low-cost data transmission electronics will be made of low-cost graphene (carbon) that is disposable and can be created using scalable manufacturing protocols.  The completed sensors will be tested in the soils surrounding tomato plants to acquire high resolution spatial and temporal nitrogen data for improving soil nitrogen models that can be utilized by farmers.  

The objective of this project is to develop bury-and-forget nitrogen sensors coupled with remote sensing technologies for real-time analysis of soil health. The sensors will be developed with flexible graphene electrodes functionalized with ionophore membranes for sensing of ammonium and nitrate ions in soils using laser inscribing and inkjet printing techniques (Aim 1). A network of these sensors will be developed using commercial Bluetooth-based mesh network modules for sensor power, computing, and communications (Aim 2). This project will elucidate the sensor depth and broadcast frequency that is capable/needed for successful in-soil nitrogen monitoring using a bucket brigade approach. This sensor network will be merged with existing crop models developed and challenged with in-field relevant conditions using a model tomato system in a testbed facility (Aim 3). The testbed facility will be used for collecting high resolution nitrogen sensor data from the soil coupled with monitoring of the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index of the plants as benchmarks to integrate remote sensing and real-time field measurements. The proposed project will lead to new: 1) wireless nitrogen sensors (both labile and mobile); 2) knowledge of spatiotemporal dynamics of soil nitrogen coupled with above ground plant physiology; 3) knowledge of scaling micro/nanosensor subsurface soil data, long-duration signal acquisition/curation, and pinpointing the maximum wireless data transmission depth in soil; and 4) best management practices for coupling soil sensor results to current field-scale tools such as remote sensing. The project will be the first to connect in-situ nanosensors, remote sensing, and crop modeling for the same sample, therein establishing a platform for improving understanding of soil biogeochemistry, sensor networks, and fundamental spatiotemporal scaling principles.  This project will facilitate rapid studies for improving empirical model parameters (crop coefficients), as well as to validate assumptions in remote sensing (links between yellowing leaves and nutrient stress) and in-situ soil sensors (nutrient fate and transport). In addition to testing the developed sensor systems, this project will establish strategies and best practices for the development, testing, and deployment of soil nutrient sensors that can be reproduced anywhere for sensor testing and/or hypothesis testing, leading to improved models and observation networks to manage soil health. Such sensor networks and resultant models are expected to lead to precision agriculture where fertilizers are spread onto specific locations of the field in a metered fashion only when needed.

por.por_cntn:
Modern agriculture crops heavily use nitrogen fertilizers to produce large yields. To ensure crop yields are as high as possible, there is a strong temptation to overapply these nitrogen fertilizers, which can be environmentally detrimental. Fertilizer-based nitrogen compounds can run off into creeks, streams, rivers and the ocean. This can cause algae blooms, loss of oxygen in water bodies, and kill fish populations. Enabling farmers to monitor their soils’ nitrogen levels will allow them to fertilize more effectively, in turn lowering costs and reducing environmental harm. The NSF EAGAR SiTs project by a project team of Iowa State researchers and University of Florida (UF) researchers, “Bury-and-forget nitrogen sensors coupled with remote sensing for soil health,” has combined inexpensive nitrogen soil sensors with bury-and-forget electronics that communicate through soil.

Using laser printing and ink jet printing for point-of-need sensing of NH4+ and NO3- ions in soils, UF and Iowa State researchers developed low nitrogen sensors fabricated on inexpensive flexible graphene surfaces. They employed electrochemical testing to determine optimal laser settings for a new model of the laser equipment used to make the sensors. This laser equipment created versions of low-cost nitrogen sensors with refined sensitivity.  

Project investigators also designed a software decision-support framework to assist in the selection of sensors for soil nitrogen through a publication database and give decision reports for users interested in checking soil nitrogen status. A simplified prototype of a smartphone-based analytical tool was created using Thunkable via Block coding to evaluate whether soil nitrogen level meets best state management practice. Microservice tools developed in this research will serve as a bridge to connect real-time in-field research with decision-support systems for nitrogen monitoring.

Additionally, UF electronics scientists buried soil measurement systems, electronic hardware, and software systems consisting of WiFi and Bluetooth modules in order to wirelessly transfer nitrogen sensor data from soil to surface. They built a network of these bury-and-forget nitrogen biosensors connected to commercial Bluetooth-based MESH network modules (Particle Industries Xenons) for sensor data storage, computing, and communications.  That MESH network formed a data bucket brigade relay at distinct depths. It moves data from buried sensors through the soil and to the surface transmitter for data transmission to the cloud. However, Particle Industries obsoleted their MESH network and the Xenon modules in December 2020. After that, the researchers designed and demonstrated a new very low power Digi MESH network that replaced the "obsoleted" Particle MESH.

The team then added the LoRa RF radio technology to the project. The long distance, low power LoRa radio technology at 900MHz is superior for buried soil sensing applications because it can penetrate soil significantly further than the 2.4GHz signals of the Bluetooth, the ISM band, and Digi MESH solutions. The scientists subsequently added soil wetness sensors and nitrogen sensors to LoRa-radio end-devices. The LoRa radios communicated nitrogen sensor data to Particle Industries Argon devices and the Argon devices relayed the data to a web server in the cloud.

This project has demonstrated designs, built, and prototyped nitrogen sensors and support electronics that can be buried underground and communicate to the cloud. However, in the last year and a half of the project, COVID-19 created lockdowns, restricted travel, and rendered face-to-face experimental work between investigators impossible. So, the research could not perform agricultural field testing of the buried nitrogen sensors with electronics communications. The agricultural field buried sensor testing of this project results will be work for future projects.
